Use case: Enable a search engine for environmental data and resources
Description: Some search engines are customizable and can be turned into usefully curated sources. Dataplanet is a customizable search engine that focuses on environmental data and resources, like WRI.org.

Use case: Search companies or topics, supported by humans in the review workflow
Description: golden.com that provides accurate semantic search on companies or topics of interest, for use in consulting, investment or financial services for example. The company Golden in particular has emphasized the synergy between machine and human curators, by enabling workflows allowing editors to improve content quality.

Use case: Offer learning options through a marketplace
Description: The learning content marketplace Teachable allows creators to generate and sell to an audience of millions of learners.

The mission is to connect people who have unusually specialized insight with seekers of that insight. For instance, professional services and consulting firms, as well as financial services ones, utilize their services to connect with experts for a few hours, to ask pointed questions that can help validate or disprove their hypotheses.

Hyperconnectivity and the ability to inventory and quality-control millions of people at minimal marginal cost has changed its dynamics radically, effectively surfacing the cognitive surplus of millions of people and reshaping many jobs. Platforms have in many respects created the current “gig economy” movement, and they increasingly show specialization of roles where very specific expertise is harnessed in a way that wasn’t possible before – an idea first publicized by MIT’s Malone and colleagues in 2011

Use case: Employees learn with others, by harnessing experts and other learners
Description: Professional services firm need to engaged in up-skilling and re-skilling large workforces at scale. The role of collaboration platforms is paramount. Team members worked from separate offices or from home. External contractors flexibly came and went. Being effective in these conditions hinged on several technology platforms. For instance, all synchronous parts of sprints and scrums took place on Zoom, with widespread use of virtual whiteboards and Microsoft Teams. Meetings led by experts used the same videoconferencing technology with an emphasis on real-time chat discussions, virtual room breakouts, and instant polls that gave SMEs rich input from the learners. SMEs themselves leveraged community sites built on Microsoft SharePoint and Teams.

Use case: Search and reading of full-text patents
Description: Google Patents enables the search and reading of full text of patents around the world, as well as identifying prior articles in non- patent literature.
Global geospatial and qualitative data about environmental abuses in local communities, mapped by citizens and researchers.

Use case: Enhance search and combine concepts from documents
Description: Knowledge management systems are increasingly complemented by what “insight engines”, that effectively enhance the search and combination of concepts excerpted from the available documents.

Who / What: Airtable, Aodocs, Bloomfire, Fireflies.ai, Humap, Notion, Slab, Slapdash
Description: Largely thanks to new cloud and AI technology, documentation and knowledge management technology is a dynamic space, with a variety of best-of-breed players also complementing and competing with the traditional enterprise software vendors – see examples such as Notion, Bloomfire, Slapdash, Slab, Aodocs, Fireflies.ai, Humap, and Airtable.

Use case: Analyze scientific and innovation literature and detect of patterns
Description: US Department of Energy’s Berkeley National Lab used NLP to create word-based bodies of text vectors in its word2vec (machine learning) algorithm, which proved to be able to predict material science’s advances

Use case: Radically unconstrained access to scientific knowledge
Description: According to Wikipedia "Sci-Hub is a shadow library website that provides free access to millions of research papers and books, without regard to copyright, by bypassing publishers' paywalls in various ways"

Metahistory's "museum of war" documents the development of Ukraine's invasion through a timeline of blockchain non-fungible tokens (NFTs) created by artists every day. The funding from sponsors is channeled to the Ukrainian government.

Use case: Scraping social media to find war equipment
Description: The Syrian Archive is an initiative using tools that scrapes social media feeds to detect and classify imagery pertaining to war equipment, with the intent of documenting and making searchable evidence of war crimes. The neural net AI curates and classifies information automatically.

Use case: Curate content as an information feeder for learners
Description: In a learning supermind the content curated acts as an information feeder for the learners. Specialized curation and learning portals identify, sort and allocate the content to the right places, such as a learning platform like EdCast, or a central knowledge repository built on a common Microsoft SharePoint.

This database contains information on more than 120,000 Recalls, Safety Alerts and Field Safety Notices about medical devices distributed worldwide. The information connects with medical device companies and their subsidiaries. Compiled by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) and 58 media partners in 36 countries during our year-long Implants File investigation, the database fills a critical information void. The data is drawn from both public sources and responses to Freedom of Information requests.

Use case: Provide environmental data through a decentralized web3 platform
Description: dClimate is a transparent, decentralized marketplace where climate data, forecasts, and models are standardized, monetized, and distributed. The marketplace connects data publishers directly with data consumers, making climate data more accessible and reliable. When data providers share data and forecasts with the market it is automatically scored for reliability, which helps consumers to shop for information. In exchange, dClimate creates a simple, direct-to-consumer distribution mechanism to monetize their work. dClimate's base layer is built on Ethereum, and the network leverages Chainlink's leading decentralized oracle network to  facilitate on-chain validation and support for dClimate's governance layer. dClimate starts on day one with a foundation of dozens of terabytes of standardized climate data ready for institutional use and anchor-client Arbol, a leading parametric weather risk platform.

Use case: Make nature-based climate credits more trustworthy
Description: Digital Gaia focuses on verifiability of nature-based solutions for climate offsets. It augments the power of a community of contributors (carbon offset project developers, data providers, data engineers) and integrates real world data with natural models to continuously evaluate regenerative project’s real global impact–from proposal to execution. It does so by using Web3 blockchain technology. It is inspired by the work of renown neuroscientist Karl Friston on active inference and minimization of free energy to optimize predictions.

Use case: Research biology through open database of proteome data
Description: OpenCell is a proteome-scale collection of protein localization and interaction measurements in human cells made thanks to CRISPR technology. It is built upon a library of 1,310 endogenously-tagged HEK293T cell lines that enables researchers to observe both protein localization (using live-cell fluorescence microscopy) and protein-protein interactions (using IP-MS) in the same cellular context.

Use case: Use citizen Observatories projects to monitor agricultural developments
Description: Expanding on GEOSS (Global Earth Observation System of Systems), the Citizen Observatories projects are funded by the European Union. One of them is GROW (soil-moisture citizen observatory) aimed at climate change and including scientists, NGOs, communities and individuals. Computer vision sifts through mixed-source (people, machines) imagery from both people and machines to enable better agricultural decisions at OneSoil.ai.

Use case: Apply image recognition software to monitor environmental changes
Description: Grevy’s Zebra Trust has the Wild Me platform to support volunteer and scientists rallies in a wildlife conservancy area. The emerging risk that these platforms need to manage is that they may inadvertently give poachers a way to find animals. Authentication and identity control can be a solution, not unlike in other parts of the web.

Use case: Add environmental data to geospatial data layers
Description: Environmental Insight Explorer (EIE)  offers the ability to append environmental data, measured or estimated, to geospatial layers enabling further insight for both organizations and end users. One of the first use cases is to help cities manage pollution.

Use case: Foster peer-to-peer community of developing-economy farmers
Description: More than a million people use Wefarm.co in Kenya and Uganda, with over 40,000 questions answered every day. Using the technology platform is very simple and is also possible through SMS for those who don’t have access to internet. Interestingly, natural language processing is utilized to facilitate the exchanges in three regional languages in addition to English.

GitHub, acquired by Microsoft, is a thriving example of collaboration collective code enhancement and reusability through a clever form of collective revision control based on its now famous forking and committing (indeed, Linus Torvald worked on the early code for that process).

Who / What: GitLab, Repl.it, Glitch.com, Codestream, Linear, JetBrains
Description: Collaborative software development technology has hence become a significant market segment, with examples such as GitLab, Repl.it, Glitch.com, Codestream, Linear, and JetBrains.

Use case: Answer coding questios and share knowledge
Description: StackOverflow is an independent, open community for anyone that codes, with the joint objective to get answers to the toughest coding questions, share knowledge with coworkers in private (and find a job, which acts as a powerful motivator). Other software vendors have been collaboration communities for many years, such as SAP Community Network.

Use case: Keep tabs on elected officials' agenda
Description: www.theyworkforyou.com enables citizens in the UK to be kept informed about the statements and action made by their democratically elected officials in a simple way. Equivalent systems have been developed for other parts of the world. Similar objective as Canada's Trudeaau Meter that monitors the premier's delivery on his commitments. And Germany's abgeordnetenwatch.de

Use case: Simplify use of crowdsourced genomics databases
Description: DNAnexus simplifies and strengthen the access to the UK Biobank database, which is one of the largest genomics databases in the world. UK BioBank has collected longitudinal clinical data from more than 500,000 people and is expected to quadruple its size in the next five years (the equivalent of adding a century of high-definition video footage). DNAnexus uses Amazon Web Services.

Use case: Use NFT to keep records of life experiences
Description: POAP.xyz is a DAO that creates badges stored as NFTs

Sia is a decentralized cloud storage platform. No signups, no servers, no trusted third parties. Sia leverages blockchain technology to create a data storage marketplace that is more robust and more affordable than traditional cloud storage providers.

In Web3, people won't need a platform to show their credentials, which could be stored in web3 technology, likely on blockchain, and would travel with them across the web. Rabbithole, Polywork and 0xStation allow users to record professional achievements on-chain.

Use case: Harness an open-access genomics and health database (UK)
Description: UK Biobank collates the medical and genomic data of 500,000 people. Each has consented to researchers using their data to better understand and prevent serious disease. And any legitimate researcher can access this resource. By 2020, more than 20,000 researchers were doing so. [Source: Azeem Azhar, "Exponential"]

GenBank, an open-access repository of genome sequences run by America’s National Institutes of Health. It was used for the first analyses of the genomic sequences of Covid-19. [Source: Azeem Azhar, "Exponential"]

Use case: Create a professional network for project-based work
Description: Polywork enables users to log in professional activities with more granularity than what's possible with established professional networks. The objective is to help workers (and demand for them) find each other based on a more fluid, gig-friendly, taxonomy.

Use case: Enable open-source mapping of power generation and other energy intensive plants
Description: Wiki based https://globalenergymonitor.org/ enable energy analysts, scientists, activists by pinpointing coal and gas plants globally, as well as wind, steel etc. Data includes capital flows and progress of building those capital assets

Use case: Enable trust at scale through distributing computing
Description: Blockchain algorithm uses the distributed computing power of thousands of blockchain miners to establish the veracity of data e.g. virtual currency in decentralized finance, or contract clauses in decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs)

Equifax and other credit scoring systems combine data points from market participants to assess trustworthiness of parties. Other examples of data-based creditworthiness assessments are FICO, Experian, TomoCredit, Kabbage.

Use case: Use blockchain for real estate registry
Description: In 2018 OpenLaw worked with various Australian lawyers to create an end-to-end real estate transaction platform that is built on the Ethereum blockchain and backed by ERC-721 NFTs. The platform enables the smooth transfer of properties through the minting of NFTs using the Australian government’s centralized records of all official land titles. While the platform is operable and successfully demonstrates the possibility of transferring land and real estate titles through blockchain technology, it would be necessary to first make changes to Australian law for the platform to be widely implemented (source Open Forest Protocol)

Use case: Use NFTs to create forestation registries
Description: Openforestprotocol.org is a community of climate change forestation project operators, validators and funders that uses blockchain technology for its records and transactions. Of particular note is the storage of immutable land-registry forestry records (including validated location, representative imagery) as non-fungible Ethereum blockchain tokens (NFTs).

Use case: Enable a collective storage database, enabled by Web3 technology
Description: As a collectively owned hard drive, Arweave allows users to remember and preserve valuable information, apps, and history indefinitely. It is an attempt to avoid the loss of knowledge due to internet page deletions, among others. Incentivized through the distribution of tokens based on "blockweave" blockchain infrastructure.
Microsoft Academic Graph (MAG) - is a scientific database with more than 236M documents

Use case: Protect individual data ownership based on public good guidelines
Description: Data trusts, where the rules are decided based on public good and guidelines shared, are another step in this direction. Open Data Institute and various national governments as well as the European Commission, are moving in that direction.

"On a typical day in the United States, police officers make more than 50,000 traffic stops. Our team is gathering, analyzing, and releasing records from millions of traffic stops by law enforcement agencies across the country. Our goal is to help researchers, journalists, and policymakers investigate and improve interactions between police and the public." (source: https://openpolicing.stanford.edu/)

“The Underlay is a global, distributed graph of public knowledge. [...] This is an attempt to replicate the richness of private knowledge graphs in a public, decentralized manner." Semantic web where knowledge can be assembled, mapped, tagged, structured to search for content in a more effective way.

Semantic MediaWiki “is a free, open-source extension to MediaWiki – the wiki software that powers Wikipedia – that lets you store and query data within the wiki's pages”. Semantic web where knowledge can be assembled, mapped, tagged, structured to search for content in a more effective way

Arxiv, the grandfather of pre-prints’ repositories started in 1994, has seen tens of millions of downloads, and has spurred the creation of specialized-domain pre-prints, such as PsyArxiv and SocArXiv and then BioArvi and Medrxiv

Use case: Use real-life driving to improve autonomous driving
Description: Tesla is capturing network dynamics thanks to its collection of data from real-life driving, that helps improving autonomous-driving algorithms. Irrespective of when it will reach full autonomous driving level, Tesla is able to enhance the lower levels thanks to its superior access to voluminous and varied data, as well as clear AI-algorithm sophistication. The emergent network dynamics are foundational to Tesla's value.

Use case: Process images to discover new things
Description: IIIF is a set of open standards for delivering high-quality, attributed digital objects online at scale. It’s also an international community developing and implementing the IIIF APIs. IIIF is backed by a consortium of leading cultural institutions.

Use case: Understand relations between knowledge and people
Description: Project Cortex is an application of graph database technology; it has become Microsoft Viva. It aims at optimizing the finding and sharing of relevant enterprise knowledge.

Use case: Collect information and help employees collaborate
Description: In many companies, the foundation of a collective knowledge feeder already exists through the convergence of three things: electronic communications, especially email and more recent collaboration environments like Slack or Microsoft Teams or, in open communities, tools like Circle; organizational structures that include subject matter expert s, e.g. practice leaders in consulting firms; and pervasive information feeds fueled by the explosion of internet-based knowledge sharing from social media to specifically curated knowledge feeds.

Who / What: Natural Language Processing (NLP) and modern audio/video encryption
Use case: Improve, translate and summarize content; optimize video and voice transmission
Description: AI branch that helps networks of people across the language spectrum, or across regions, connect increasingly meaningfully with each other.
Xerox Eureka community helped share knowledge across technicians. One of the first crowdsourced technical community forums in the world.

Powered by NLP and federated search, Neuron7 understands the human context of questions to find the exact answer on the right page from among thousands of KB articles, product manuals, and support call transcripts, etc. Its intent is to unlock tribal knowledge that is often trapped in documentation created in the flow of work by experts and other workers.

The InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) is a protocol and peer-to-peer network for storing and sharing data in a distributed file system. IPFS uses content-addressing to uniquely identify each file in a global namespace connecting all computing devices
Farming peer-sharing, decision-making platform for small farmers. Exchange of practices, dynamically evolving as new conditions emerge

Wolfram Alpha uses smarter, AI based, semantic analysis to understand language and return the right information from an openly-accessible corpus. Wolfram Alpha relies on both semantics and curated, structured data derived from internet data sources. The new generation of search engines uses smarter, AI based, semantic analysis to understand language and return the right information.

Medical school and crowdsourced environments like PatientsLikeMe can help medical communities get smarter about what has worked in specific circumstances in the past, sparing individuals the need to form those experiences directly.

Use case: Industrialize the finding, improving, and sharing of valuable knowledge
Description: Many consulting firms have communities of practice that form around appointed leaders and serve as watering holes for consultants. However, in this case, the firm uses those nodes as deliberate actors of a tightly knit learning platform enabling the reskilling of tens of thousands of employees. An important element of this infrastructure is the exoskeleton of resources that helps the knowledge nodes to scale. Knowledge management curators, community managers, and advanced analytics that feed the nodes with the latest information about learning patterns and learner experience diagnostics, nodes obtain a rich feedback loop from the system and redirect the execution accordingly.

Apart from showing connections between papers, connectedpapers.com and researchrabbit.ai enable the visualization of the connection between authors in ways that would be impossible just with citation maps.
System is a free, open, and living public resource that aims to explain how anything in the world is related to everything else - built on a graph database of natural language.
The Biblissima Portal provides unified access to a set of digital data on medieval manuscripts, incunabula and early printed books.
Platform for creating and selling online courses. Members of specialized communities like this one are harnessed surgically for commerce.

DigiVatLib is a digital library service. It provides free access to the Vatican Library’s digitized collections: manuscripts, incunabula, archival materials and inventories as well as graphic materials, coins and medals, printed materials (special projects).

Use case: Improve patients therapy by combining human practices through machine learning
Description: The Human Diagnosis Project (Human Dx) is a worldwide effort created with and led by the global medical community to build an online system that maps the steps to help any patient. By combining collective intelligence with machine learning, Human Dx intends to enable more accurate, affordable, and accessible care for all. "Let's end unequal access to medical knowledge" is their motto.

Use case: Nurture communities of experts that complement in-house customer interaction teams
Description: Nurture communities of experts that complement your in-house customer interaction teams. Use deep semantic analysis to understand trends. Ensure that product management teams are connected in a bi-directional way so that they can learn from new queries and help create knowledge artifacts to feed the distributed problem solvers.
Elicit uses language models like GPT-3 to search materials on the web, and do so more richly than normal search. Initially focused on scientific research and particularly empirical studies.

"Ed Hawkins, a climate scientist at the University of Reading in England, put out a call for help transcribing more than 65,000 handwritten logs of monthly rainfall, spanning three centuries, from across Britain and Ireland. The writing in the records was too irregular to be read by machine; human eyes were needed. More than 16,000 people answered Dr. Hawkins’s request, and together they chewed through the task in a little over two weeks. That was [...] during Britain’s first coronavirus lockdown. [By early 2022], the nation’s weather agency, the Met Office, [had] processed 3.3 million data points from the transcribed pages and added them to its national rainfall statistics, enriching the official record with many more observations and extending it back to 1836." (Source: The New York Times)

Can ecosystems decide? Ecosystems benefit from the natural experiments that happen in loosely connected parts of the network and can provide significant creativity as well as resiliency. They’re however harder to align and control. Nature effectively chooses, over time, based on alternatives created by mutations of genes and the environment; it expresses those genes in the short term through epigenetics (for instance metabolic changes in response to a famine, transmitted to the next generation); and mutations of RNA seem to show longer-term "memory" of the reaction to biological event (such as in the case of mounting a defense to a bacteria)
LOC corwdsourcing organizes virtual volunteering to transcribe, review, and tag Library digital collections to improve discovery.
GEDMatch enables people to find DNA relatives across many DNA databanks.

Who / What: Large communities from Apple, PatientsLikeMe, Wikipedia
Use case: Produce intellectual property or curate knowledge
Description: Can communities create and store technical knowledge? Online communities are one of the largest emerging social phenomena of the last quarter-century. Apple is one of the most prominent nodes, and the algorithms of both Facebook and YouTube exercise significant control on how those communities behave. Communities provide creativity and additional resources that are typically not accessible by normal hierarchical organization. But they’re harder to set up and direct.

Use case: Generate a repository of internet page structures
Description: The flow of social media curated for each of us relies on algorithms that examine our Twitter network, or the communities on Reddit or LinkedIn. A repository of free internet page structures is offered by Commoncrawl.org.

Communities of enthusiasts could use virtual reality (metaverse) world to recreate past environments, by crowdsourcing its components. For instance, by rebuilding a city as it was when they were young, replete with the popular hangouts of the time as well as the soundscape and other paraphernalia (such as clothing, popular items etc). The same could be done for historical sites. The ability of new AI technology to create 3D models from 2D imagery will greatly simplify the work that amateurs could do, hence exponentially increasing the diversity and granularity that could be generated. Participants could be incentivized in the creation of VR models through the use of NFTs.

Can communities be used to make employees learn? There is an opportunity to enlist subject matter experts to curate knowledge and support the enterprise learning. GE-spinoff and digital business operations provider Genpact offers instructive insights on how that architecture helps people learn and use fast- changing skills in more scalable ways. They also cost a fraction of the traditional learning and development (L&D) and knowledge-management costs.

Use case: Open-source agricultural seeds breeding and distribution
Description: Bioleft is a community of open source seed exchange and breeding to offer solutions to the challenges of agriculture. In their words: "Bioleft is a community that builds an open seed exchange and breeding network to offer alternative solutions to the challenges of agriculture. Based on collective intelligence, open knowledge, agreements and solidarity, we develop social and technological innovations that allow the exchange of information. We link local and scientific knowledge to enhance the role of farmers in seed conservation and breeding. In this way they generate a greater availability of biodiverse and resilient seeds, considered as a commons."

Use case: Channel public-service requests from individual constituencies
Description: Citizens in many democratic countries typically have the right to ask information to their representative institutions, but the process is often complicated which results in many people giving up. Tools like MySociety.org' Whatdotheyknow.org helps making those requests easier. It's active in the United Kingdom and many other countries.
https://farmhack.org/tools crowdsources tooling blueprints

Scite uses scientific citations and natural language processing to identify which people are authoritative in which topics, and what they say. In doing so, it also ensures that credit is given to original thinking.

Use case: Make citations more accurate on the web
Description: Meta has trained Side, a natural language understanding model that can help improve and audit the quality of citations in documents published online.

Use case: Collect legal language in common-law systems
Description: Public.resource.org is a repository of laws and bylaws collected into a free-to-access common database. In the United States, it attempts to address the problem posed by the availability of much legal language only in payable resources such as legal databases, which penalize citizens and smaller organizations with limited financial means.

Use case: Barter time in a peer to peer marketplace
Description: Experts barter time and are matched to requests for help related to their area of expertise. Time is used as a currency.

Use case: Source and monetize people's data fairly
Description: Pooldata.io's platform supports organizations who enable ordinary people to monetize and share their data. Pool calls these Data Unions. And because those people are positively engaged in sharing their information, data products on Pool’s platform are richer, more relevant, and far easier to license. Pool aims to make it easy to manage business and governance structures, known as Data Unions from creation through to data aggregation, payment and buyer engagement.

Use case: Authenticate personally-identifiable credentials on blockchain technology
Description: In Web3, people won't need a platform to authenticate them. Their identity and credentials could be stored in web3 technology, likely on blockchain, and would travel with them across the web. Violet aims to authenticate off-chain, personally identifiable information on-chain.

Use case: Provide community based courses for creatives
Description: Domestika.org is a learning community for creative minds, where the best experts and practitioners share their knowledge and skills through professionally produced online courses and content. The courses cover a broad creative spectrum, from illustration and design to crafts and digital marketing, and beyond. The platform offers nearly 2,000 courses taught by 1,300 creative professionals.

Use case: Fight office burnout with positive gossip
Description: Gossip can often go viral and have "meme" quality. Can managers be thought to use positive gossip that uses network effects to help create an atmosphere of positivity which fight office burnout? Network theories about "complex contagion" (Kristakis, Fowler) support this hypothesis. (See also Jennifer Moss "The Burnout Epidemic").

Use case: Enable citizens to increase transparency, accountability, and community effectiveness
Description: www.mysociety.org is an NGO based in the UK whose technology is used in dozens of countries, to enable citizens so they can keep their institutions more accountable and informed. They do so by improving the user experience in doing things that democratic institutions are mandated to do, but often don't make it easy to happen - such as alerting public authorities or public officials about local problems, or requesting information from them.

Use case: Harness large database of satellite imagery for data science
Description: Google Earth Engine combines a multi-petabyte catalog of satellite imagery and geospatial datasets with planetary-scale analysis capabilities. Scientists, researchers, and developers use Earth Engine to detect changes, map trends, and quantify differences on the Earth's surface. Earth Engine is available for commercial use, and remains free for academic and research use. (Source: Google)

Use case: Maintain a dataset of building footprints to support social good applications
Description: Building footprints are useful for a range of important applications, from population estimation, urban planning and humanitarian response, to environmental and climate science. This large-scale open dataset contains the outlines of buildings derived from high-resolution satellite imagery in order to support these types of uses. The project being based in Ghana, the current focus is on the continent of Africa. https://sites.research.google/open-buildings/
Natural language model SciBert is an attempt to train AI to answer natural language queries on scientific knowledge.

Use case: Use mobile devices for improving policing
Description: Android application called CopCast – turning smartphones into police body-worn cameras in Brazil. https://igarape.org.br/en/apps/smart-policing/

Use case: Enable gig worker marketplace on Web3
Description: Usebraintrust.com matches supply of skilled freelancers with demand, and uses a blockchain based infrastructure (including DAO decision making) to cut off traditional intermediaries. It is technically owned by the user community (which include the Braintrust software development team)

Founders, funders, creatives, and creators need a dedicated place to collect and connect the dots. Startupy plans to be a community-powered database for startup knowledge, organized associatively. Startupy would incentivize experts to contribute startup knowledge and gain an internet-wide reputation in specific domains.

With Ceramic's permissionless data streaming network, one can store streams of information (including web3 user identifier data that can travel with the user) and ever-changing files directly on the decentralized web – and share updates with anyone in the world.

The US Public Library of Science launched in early 2022 a freely accessible journal supported by a global editorial board with the mission of sharing some of the best and most important climate research (https://journals.plos.org/climate/) and offer a conduit for the dissemination of interdisciplinary work that crosses the boundaries of traditional disciplinary siloes.

Use case: Use traditional cultures' knowledge to enrich modern science
Description: Traditional cultures' knowledge accumulated over thousands of years with limited contact with the West (for instance Amazonas Indians medecines or Australian natives fire control methods), is increasingly used as a source of valuable information that can complement, add to, and give inspiration to modern science.

Monitoring and assessing civilian harm from airpower-dominated international military actions. Seeking transparency and accountability from belligerents, and advocating on behalf of affected non-combatants. Archiving open-source casualty reports, and military claims by nations. Based on social media and volunteer triangulation.

CureAccelerator supports “proof of concept” research repurposing drugs, devices and nutriceuticals already approved for human use. On CureAccelerator, funders have direct access to repurposing research, researchers can post ideas and connect with peers and funding, and clinicians can contribute their experience of off-label use in need of validation.
Crowdsourced, anonymized surfacing of instances of bribes encountered by citizens in India when dealing with their public services providers
Platform enabling citizens to lodge anonymous or confidential complaints against public Indonesian bodies. https://www.lapor.go.id/

Use case: Summarizing the insights for climate change science
Description: The IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel for Climate Change) report, for instance its major 2022 release, is a global effort to summarize the entire scientific fact base around climate science, in an attempt to influence public policy and industry strategy. Its output is an inventory of the research published and its principal conclusions.

Indonesia's commercial drivers organically created a supporting community centered around Twitter, called Gojer on Twit (GoT). The organization helped them counter the information advantage that ride-hailing algorithms have over individual workers.
This website identifies and visualizes political ads on Facebook for the purpose of monitoring and analyzing them

Use case: Redesign healthcare by surfacing health communities ideas
Description: "Contributing towards care provision reform. opencare aims at studying on what constitutes best practice in the field of community based collective intelligence projects in the field of care provision, and on how these solutions might be integrated in national social and health care systems. The opencare consortium will develop a software stack to monitor and assist collective intelligence social dynamics in online communities. We develop software to help the community make sense by identifying points of consensus and controversy, summarizing, and structuring arguments."

Metafluidics is a design repository where contributors can store their design of microfluids, and others can use them and develop them further. It is an open-source repository where you can upload the device designs for all kinds of fluidics systems, from diagnostic devices to devices for PCR, assembling DNA, or cell culture.

Huggingface.co uses a community to inventory mostly Natural Language Processing (NLP) code, especially pretrained models for specific use cases and hardware. The community also helps making the code better. Its infrastructure shares commonalities with GitHub.

Plume's technologies provide air quality information for any location —getting right down to street level in over 100 major cities around the world. They draw on over 12,000 monitoring stations and own models, integrating a large amount of data including weather information, population density, land-use and road networks.

Search engines don't structure research topics well, but other NLP tools like Gyan.ai attempt to provide richer content quality by using a combination of web and database search, and knowledge graph technology.

Use case: Using web3 to build scientists' reputation
Description: Currently, scientists’ reputations — and as a result their ability to secure funding — are tied to publishing metrics. With blockchain technology, scientists could earn NFTs for doing other activities that research communities deem valuable, such as peer review, training and mentoring, and sharing data openly. NFT collections could act as a verifiable digital reputation for contributions, further incentivizing such behaviors. Scientists and groups of individuals with a shared wallet, such as a decentralized lab, could build reputation this way. Source: Sarah Hamburg.
Meetup.com enables people to quickly find an extensive set of people with similar interests, both in person or virtually.
https://www.frogid.net.au/ empowers volunteers in the field to log sightings, so that other volunteers can study patterns that might hold clues on the depletion of natural stock of frogs.

Use case: Improve human performance through crowdsourced AR (concept)
Description: A builder could be guided on his work by a more-experience, perhaps even retired, remote colleague who is working from home: both use augmented reality goggles to see what each other sees. 4G and certainly 5G make the transmission of data fast and detailed. This model can be applied to any field where an in-field operator may lack the skills to deal with unusual circumstances, while a remote pool of experts can serve multiple in-field operators. Applications can range from remote healthcare through paramedics and first responders, to installation of new climate-neutral energy assets such solar panels or insulation, to deployment of new agricultural and forestry methods.

Use case: Harness citizen science for detecting light pollution
Description: Globe at Night is an international citizen-science campaign to raise public awareness of the impact of light pollution by inviting citizen-scientists to measure & submit their night sky brightness observations.

Biodiversity loss through illegal poaching of animals is also causing deforestation. Rainforest connection is helping to direct limited resources on the ground, e.g. deploying park rangers to the locations that they are needed. Finally bioacoustic monitoring is providing a unique dataset for local ecologists, helping them to improve outcomes for the reintroduction of key species. https://rfcx.org/our_work

The Open Apparel Registry exists to improve human rights and environmental conditions in and around factories and facilities by opening up supply chain data as a free, public good. When everyone working in global supply chains enjoys equal access to quality, open-licensed data, it leads to more sustainable and equitable outcomes for the most vulnerable communities affected by the apparel sector.

OpenEarth uses common standards and open-source digital infrastructure to create an Operating System for planet Earth, by consolidating Earth system observations in shared digital records and enable collective action and accountability on a global scale.

Use case: Collate data about the planet's resources
Description: Resource Watch features hundreds of data sets all in one place on the state of the planet’s resources and citizens. Users can visualize challenges facing people and the planet, from climate change to poverty, water risk to state instability, air pollution to human migration, and more.

Use case: Use open-source energy data to improve forecasts
Description: In 2022, the International Energy Agency (IEA) announced that it would make much of its data sets open for the public to access and use for modeling, in the hope of improving cost and availability predictions among others. This is an important step in enabling communities to study countermeasures to climate change. The agency is funded mostly by governments, and has been criticized in the past because its predictions of renewable costs (particularly solar) systematically overshot the actual outcomes, making the renewables transition feel in some cases more expensive than it would actually be.
Promote knowledge sharing and advance collaborative water stewardship
Apart from OpenStreetMap, other technologies such as MapBox and Mapillary and https://tasks.hotosm.org/ are available.

Use case: Enable society's open innovation through IoT sensors, data and processing
Description: Taiwan's governance enourages the open collection of IoT data, its storage and processing. Objective is to create applications that help resiliance in case of disasters and environmental challenges. https://ci.taiwan.gov.tw/
Interactive, crowdsourced map of tree assets and their positive impact
Source network is a blockchain based infrastructure with decentralized tools and infrastructure that prioritize data interoperability, privacy preservation, and trustless ownership.

Academia.edu, a portal providing a large array of scientific publications, offers "summaries" of research as a premium service, enabling the swift identification and combination of relevant ideas across a large corpus of knowledge.

Inuit ice knowledge combined with geospatial data. Community driven mapping of ice conditions and interpretation of related risks, to increase safety https://en.unesco.org/courier/2019-1/siku-mixing-high-tech-ancient-know-how
https://preciousplastic.com/solutions/machines/overview.html

Filecoin (⨎) is an open-source, public cryptocurrency and digital payment system intended to be a blockchain-based cooperative digital storage and data retrieval method. It builds on top of InterPlanetary File System allowing users to rent unused hard drive space. A blockchain mechanism is used to register the deals. Filecoin is an open protocol and backed by a blockchain that records commitments made by the network’s participants, with transactions made using FIL, the blockchain’s native currency. The blockchain is based on both proof-of-replication and proof-of-spacetime.

Use case: Enable community driven weather watch in Colorado
Description: CoCoRaHS "is a grassroots volunteer network of backyard weather observers of all ages and backgrounds working together to measure and map precipitation (rain, hail and snow) in their local communities. By using low-cost measurement tools, stressing training and education, and utilizing an interactive Web-site, our aim is to provide the highest quality data for natural resource, education and research applications."

Halogen is a community-based platform running transparent peer-to-peer validation protocols based on web3 technology. The intent is to build an accurate, representative, and usable knowledge base by creating an alternative validation channel for science, eliminating the need for traditional journals.

In 2010, the Mexican government introduced a performance evaluation system across all departments to keep track of the impact of public programming and spending. The system, based on the Logical Framework methodology from USAID, is intended to increase accountability and improve results of public service delivery. Over the years it has been used by civil servants across the government to keep track of their progress against a set of indicators unique to each public spending initiative. The evaluation includes open text entries where civil servants write a brief justification to account for goals that weren’t met. The UNDP Accelerator Lab is mining the text entries using NLP to cluster and rank dominant themes across this vast public service dataset. By training an AI model to compare text entries with a set of predefined common causes and identify novel themes, they’re aiming to improve the reporting process for civil servants in the future. The algorithm is enabling them to analyze and make use of civil-servant generated data that’s otherwise too unstructured for centralized analysis. Eventually the team hopes to build a hybrid collective intelligence model, where the quality of evaluations is improved by combining NLP classification and inputs from civil servants in real time. (Source: UNDP, Nesta UK)
Using GPT-3 CODEX, Copilot suggests code lines or entire functions, to make coding more efficient and help beginners. Amazon launched CodeWhisperer in 2022, with a similar concept and objective.

Proactively bring pro-social voices into the community forums. An example of this is Google Jigsaw, which for instance was used to build anti-terrorism narratives leveraging AdWords and YouTube in an effort to disrupt ISIS’ recruitment networks

Use case: Create network effect for consumers and e-commerce
Description: Tencent's subsidiaries have created significant network dynamics across connecting people, giving them incentives to collaborate, and providing an environment where it is safe (or at least it is perceived to be safe, within sometime-politicized boundaries) to do so.
Credentials as an incentive: Methods like Lean Six Sigma, leverage mastery through publicly-recognized credentials to keep people going.

Use case: Use social capital and trust as drivers of network effectiveness and incentives
Description: Grameen Bank has shown that social networks can enable trust mechanisms that allow provision of credit to previously “unbankable” communities.

Use case: Identify role of influencers and people with clout
Description: Influencers and people with significant clout could inject themselves at crucial junctures in the threads and conversations, and visibly endorse or praise people – or simple show with their presence that they matter. Senior executives do that systematically. The use of network analytics and technologies like Microsoft Workplace Analytics can help network influencers to pinpoint the intervention points and be more efficient.
Legal action crowdfunding – which echoes funding by citizens in Singapore, for instance.

Use case: Help the "collective healthcare mind remember” solutions
Description: A knowledge feeder also helps the collective mind “remember” what has worked elsewhere. For instance, medical- school instruction, or crowdsourced environments like PatientsLikeMe can help medical communities get smarter about what has worked in specific circumstances in the past, sparing the individuals the need to form those experiences directly. PatientsLikeMe is a particularly interesting example, because of their collaboration started in 2017 with Chinese AI company iCarbonX whose stated intent is to “digitize the components of life”.

Fueled by the incubation of “hypercuration” ideas made by companies like Substack and Medium, in late 2020 and early 2021, a variety of alternative models started emerging. Forums like Clubhouse and Twitter Super Follows showed that smaller audiences, relying on a more intimate connection with the creators, could also be financially attractive and, hopefully, yield more thoughtful, insightful, and civil information feeders.
At the end of 2020, the introduction of Clubhouse created a new hybrid: real-time audio-only conversations, in private invite-only rooms, where (typically) influencers host discussion in which participants can raise hand and intervene. This one-to-many model is de-facto a hybrid between social media (podcasting) and unified communications. While it is too early to tell if this model would be effective, in early 2021 Clubhouse was already valued as a Unicorn.

Use case: Store and retrieve all world news
Description: To tap into news trends, G-DELT, a global database of published sources, auto-translated from dozens of languages and available as a public resource or through Google Big Query is a great resource. The globally- sourced news repository G-DELT disgorges machine-translated news from thousands of publicly accessible sources worldwide. It has the ability to identify newsworthy actions taken by billions of people: from adaptation to water scarcity, to early detection of potential conflicts due to environmental stress, to surfacing of the perceived popularity and adoption of public policies, the world becomes a petri dish that teams elsewhere can read, avoiding the proverbial reinvention of the wheel.

Google search queries have been used to gain a new perspective on social dynamics. They can identify to the gap between declared and actual behavior (many lie to pollsters, but few lie to a search engine text- input field). Another obvious application is healthcare: Google Health was discontinued in 2011 but examination of search queries haves, for instance, been used to shed light on health needs in the African continent by exploring which demographic segments are interested in certain types of cures.

Use case: Generate realistic and cogent natural language
Description: OpenAI’s GPT-3, a language model trained on one of the largest knowledge datasets in the world, is increasingly able to summarize natural language and other text-based knowledge. Think of it as a “auto-complete” on steroids, but with an unprecedented ability to synthesize information, and even doing so in fascinating ways, for instance by using a specific corpus of data that would, say, enable it to simulate the answers that a person (say, Alan Touring), would provide to a specific question [...] GPT-3 could also radically alter how people write code, by enabling millions to provide plain-English instruction and let the neural network do the rest.

Use case: Generate realistic and cogent natural language
Description: Initially engineered by Google, Transformers are a new architecture that enables computers to understand language with radically improved accuracy, and they’re architecturally the fourth archetypes of neural networks (after convolutional and recurrent neural networks, and multilayer perceptrons).

Use case: Enable physical-environment monitoring through crowdsourced, tech-enabled sensors
Description:
Takingspace.org’s Airbeam enables crowd-based “aircasting”, i.e. the monitoring and analysis of pollution exposure across large groups of people. A competitor of Airbeam, Awair also measures pollution exposure through grassroots contributions. A competitor of Airbeam, Awair also measures pollution exposure through grassroots contributions.
Co-timed with Earth Day 2020, Microsoft launched its “Planetary Computer” project, aimed at collecting, storing and processing (through AI) data sourced across the planet, and make it available to researchers, including citizen scientists.
Meanwhile, Safecast is the collective, citizen-led response to Fukushima’s nuclear reactor failure, when hundreds of DIY radioactivity sensors were deployed by laypeople, enabling a fast response to the crisis. It also deployed IoT devices to detect radiation.

Use case: Scale the Mapping and sharing of observations of biodiversity
Description: The iNaturalist community (an effort run by the California Academy of Science and the National Geographic Society) uses specialized computer vision specialized classifiers to allow the mapping and sharing of observations of biodiversity across the globe using a free mobile app and has contributed more than 60 million observations of more than 300,000 species.
In the UK, a network of sensors tracks biodiversity degradation.

Use case: Map human responses to adverse weather events
Description:
The Mexican state of Tabasco has been mapping human behavior in response to adverse weather events, combining mobile and other sensor data, to pinpoint needs and interventions. The effort is part of the “UN Global Pulse”, harnessing support from the respective UN agency, the World Food Program, and local constituencies. 
A comparable effort is at play in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, where the Ramani Huria project, (based on OpenStreetMap – an open sourced mapping effort), helps local communities map relevant infrastructure and land features especially in informal human settlements.

Use case: Use image recognition software for biosphere tracking (animals in the wild)
Description: Oregon-based Wild Me's software provides image recognition to cameras positioned in the wild – so that individuals can be tracked as they move in their habitat.

An array of companies are using crowds to train algorithms. Mozilla’s Common Voice initiative uses crowdsourced voices to train speech recognition software. Captcha, the now- famous method to enable authentication for user sign in with the objective of limiting automated login and related misuse of internet assets, was initially conceived as a clever mechanism to use people to help machines tag visual content from millions of scanned books that computerized character recognition couldn’t decipher. It is in a way the largest crowdsourcing effort in the world. Amazon used it for tagging millions of pictures with humans – which spawned Amazon Mechanical Turk, the grandfather of crowdsourcing platforms.

Use case: Create maps and correct computer-created maps
Description: Europe’s BlackShore.eu uses gamified crowdsourcing to create maps; it operates in a similar space as OpenStreetMap

Use case: Generate Multisourced / crowdsourced maps for healthcare
Description: Healthmap.org “delivers real-time intelligence on a broad range of emerging infectious diseases for a diverse audience including libraries, local health departments, governments, and international travelers. HealthMap brings together disparate data sources, including online news aggregators, eyewitness reports, expert- curated discussions and validated official reports, to achieve a unified and comprehensive view of the current global state of infectious diseases and their effect on human and animal health. Through an automated process, updating 24/7/365, the system monitors, organizes, integrates, filters, visualizes and disseminates online information about emerging diseases in nine languages, facilitating early detection of global public health threats.”
In Wikipedia, mastery is a strong driver for community members’ efforts.

Use case: Use mastery as a form of work satisfaction
Description: In consulting firms, Practice Leaders and in general SMEs derive part of their satisfaction from that mastery – and by sharing it with the people around them, as well as obtaining powerful feedback from those networks.

For over a decade, OpenStreetMap's thousands of volunteers have toiled to provide an open source alternative to commercial geo-mapping, further annotating and correcting computer-vision-detected terrain. Additional uses of this networked intelligence include rapid re- mapping of areas impacted by natural disasters.

Every big collective effort, from Wikipedia to Linux, has always walked a tightrope around allocating credit to many contributors while recognizing the leadership of central nodes. Successful networks ultimately avoid concentrating rewards or glorifying one person.
Procter & Gamble has a mature open innovation system through which a network of partners inject novel ideas into their portfolio and co-create new products.
Marketplace for job advice and professional networking for more job types than LinkedIn (inlcuding non-office jobs).
While not fully managed, these communities benefit from infrastructure and rules that a third party has created. For example, LinkedIn has interest groups that connect people with shared knowledge.
WhatsApp and similar support groups that form around communities of disenfranchised and abused expatriate workers from poor countries.
Facebook group “Welt Frauen” (German for “World’s Women”) is constituted of German-speaking female expatriates who exchange tips and even accommodation listings.
Quantopian's contests, populated by thousands of “quants” from various fields, aim at creating new, and radically diverse, financial markets trading algorithms.

Bought by IKEA, TaskRabbit helps to find anything from handymen to anyone who could help running errands. It has a credential and trust system based on user ratings in addition to the company’s vetting, as well as a transaction-clearing system that takes care of anything from payment to exception management.
One of the first and most established contractor marketplaces
Ubuntoo is a Service provider that brings together experts and knowledge, focused on environmental sustainability innovation.

Who / What: Bank of America social network analytics
Description: BofA has applied social network analysis to support the data analytics needed to provide feedback and incentives to network participants.
GM has applied social network analysis to support the data analytics needed to provide feedback and incentives to network participants.

Microsoft Teams’ “Who Bot” is an example of artificial intelligence bots deployed to identify the relevant people in a network, so they can be accessed by those who need them. Similarly, Profinda, Starmind, Elqano and WhoKnows are AI-augmented graph databases specialized in the automated identification of experts.

To map relevant people and “illuminate” the external network we first need to precisely define the language for topics of interest which can be disambiguated through what is called “entity extraction”, which helps identify the semantic field, i.e. the words, that reflect that theme – for instance “artificial intelligence” and “machine learning” and “neural network” would be branches and separate entities. The next step is some social media scraping and searching for connections or followers of initial nodal people. For instance, experts in reskilling would likely follow a few dozen core experts in that field. Having a database of key people can help connecting them.

Use case: Improve hedge fund decisions through strong debate
Description: Most companies have relatively primitive skill inventories (i.e. know which people has what skills), and even fewer apply that knowledge in decision-making processes. Credibility is conveyed informally, either through rank or executive presence – and both can be flawed inputs to decision-making. While the complexity of that task is understandable, it seems intuitive that is a gap. One company that has put Significant attention into this is Ray Dalio's Bridgewater, and their dot system, where people rate each other nonstop to weigh people's opinions and reach the best decisions. They do so through algorithmic analysis of their collective cognitive process and allocate people accordingly.

Use case: Discover the traits of successful teams
Description: Google's Aristotle project showed that psychological safety is a key metric, and that highly effective teams define individual roles precisely. Also showed that one of the most accurate predictors of teams’ effectiveness was clarity of goals and roles. In studying quantitatively the determinants of performance of highly interconnected teams, a key parameter identified was, in addition to clarity of goals, “meaning” - a sense of purpose.

Homogeneity and diversity should be intentionally designed – the former for fast and efficient execution, the latter for broadening the world view and exploring new dynamics of collaboration.Teamscope.io is an example of technology intended to provide diagnostic tools to initiate that process, enabling a better understanding of where team members (though not large network’s) stand compared to each other.

Use case: Enable match-making through sophisticated data-driven detection of affinity signals
Description: TikTok does away with people networks as a driver for curation, and cuts straight to interpreting interest in the content itself. There is Significant potential innovation in this space, possibly through smarter algorithms whose match making is based on stronger knowledge graphs interpreting affinity signals or drawing from network analytics.

Who / What: Nippon Foundation and GEBCO Seabed project
Description: The Nippon Foundation and GEBCO Seabed project, launched in 2017, has by now mapped over 10% of the Earth’s oceanic floors. The next phase will include crowdsourcing of data by appending echo- sounding equipment to all sorts of vessels, based on their routes. Along similar lines, swarms of bots could possibly one day act as sensor networks canvassing larger spaces in a dynamic, adaptable manner.

Use case: Allow experts to expand their networks externally and internally
Description: Experts have sources of information – from trade contacts to client engagements – and can tap into their pre-existing networks. The networked intelligence model enables them to expand that network both externally (as knowledge managers help comb external sources more thoroughly) and internally. The latter is quite important. Thousands of people can now provide the experts feedback from the natural experiments that they carry out daily. They also re-direct to the experts any interesting tidbits of knowledge that they might come across. As a backbone to all of this, multiple Microsoft Teams channels facilitate the interaction between experts and knowledge managers.

Amazon has established a strong market "ecosystem" that leverages its supply chain platform, arguably one of the most sophisticated and commercially powerful in the world. They control some high-leverage points in the system, such as pricing, client engagement, logistics policies. The result is emerging network intelligence whose outcomes are continuous adaptation and, so far, market success.

Speakers of languages like Chinese and English, where the corpus of data is large and the language translation more accurate, will become more interoperable. Speakers of language with a vast corpus of language data for management, science and engineering applications (Japanese, German, French, Russian) will also benefit. With companies like Appen and Lionbridge continuing to use crowdsourcing to enhance translation algorithms for specialized uses, other languages may quickly become available for machine-assisted translations. Soon, Spanish, Italian, or Indonesian speakers could see their accented English recognized more accurately by translation apps, limiting the need for machine translation of their native languages.

Use case: Use flight data for decentralized analysis
Description: Routes of airplanes (e.g., through FlightRadar24) and ships are available publicly, which adds data to understand, among others, CO2 emissions sources.
Use of knowledge graphs to curate media sources (in English)

Use case: Discover Weekly to encourage diversity in media consumption
Description: To prevent media bubbles, we can rework the algorithms for instance by introducing rules that limit the amount of unproven information they feed to large groups, or force serendipity into the choices of content served (an example of this is Spotify Discover Weekly functionality that can encourage exploration beyond one’s comfort zone)

Superstar developers code side-by-side, complementing each other’s brain in real-time. Sanjay Ghemawat and Jeff Dean, the founding fathers of MapReduce, are the only level-11 coders at Google (the highest level in that expertise hierarchy). Without them, we wouldn't have Hadoop, big data would still be out of reach, and Google wouldn't be what it is. Sitting side by side, they code on the same machine, complementing each other’s brain in real-time.

Stablecoins seek to maintain a constant value of a token relative to some asset, most commonly the U.S. dollar or other major fiat currency. Non-custodial stablecoins function as DeFi services themselves. Custodial stablecoins are centralized but may be incorporated into DeFi services. An example is DAI (governed by MakerDAO) based on Ethereum.

Exchanges allow users to trade one digital asset for another. DeFi exchanges avoid taking custody of user assets, either through a decentralized order book or by matching orders and setting prices algorithmically. Uniswap and SushiSwap are examples.

Credit involves the creation of time-limited interest-bearing instruments, which must be repaid at maturity, and the matching of lenders and borrowers to issue those instruments. Flash loans are an example, enabling borrowing from decentralized protocols such as Aave and dYdX. Another example is Compound “a money market protocol that lets users instantly lend to or borrow from a pool of assets in a smart contract”

Derivatives are synthetic financial instruments whose value is based on a function of an underlying asset or group of assets. Common examples are futures and options, which reference the value of an asset at some time in the future. An example is Synthetix, a synthetic asset issuance protocol built on Ethereum.

Insurance provides protection against risks by trading the payment of a guaranteed small premium for the possibility of collecting a large payout in the event of a covered scenario. Asset management seeks to maximize the value of an asset portfolio based on risk preferences, time horizons, diversification, or other conditions. An example is NexusMutual which offers smart contract insurance cover, for protection against a smart contract bug, in the UK.

Use case: Perform financial Asset Management through DeFi
Description: Asset management seeks to maximize the value of an asset portfolio based on risk preferences, time horizons, diversification, or other conditions. An example is Set Protocol, a decentralized portfolio management protocol enabling users to create a token that represents a fully collateralized portfolio of other digital assets, including Bitcoin, Ethereum, and stablecoins.

Use case: Use genomic surveillance networks to detect Covid-19 variants
Description: When additional variants of the virus started to emerge, genomic surveillance networks across the world proved invaluable – for instance, the Africa Pathogen Genomics Initiative, first established to track Ebola and yellow fever. [Source: Azeem Azhar, "Exponential"]
Boat rental peer-to-peer rental community Boatsetter connects sea lovers, boat owners, and licensed captains.

Citimart is a platform that helps cities to get more innovative in their procurement processes, by enlarging the vendor and subject matter experts’ pools, and enables the sharing of outcomes and learnings from respective implementations.

Use case: Form a combined perception of reality
Description: According to Jeff Hawkins' "Thousand Brains" theory, the brain does not contain one model of the world; it contains thousands of complementary models for everything we know. The models vote together to produce our singular perception.

Use case: Label datasets for AI by frontline responders, human-in-the-loop technology development
Description: Ensuring human oversight of algorithms after deployment can help to identify and correct these errors in a timely manner. For this project, a group of volunteers from the Montgomery County Community Emergency Response Team (MCERT) helped to check and correct labels assigned by the AI classifier. This participatory approach, known as human-in-the-loop, was used to verify the classifications being made by the system and correct any mistakes in real time. The process also resulted in a novel image dataset with expert labels of damage to further train the algorithm and improve its accuracy during future deployments.During the two-week period that followed the landfall of Hurricane Dorian, the system was deployed to collect and filter social media images. Approximately 160,000 images were tagged as relevant by the system, with ~26,000 of these containing some damage content. All images that the system ranked as severe or mild were sent for human validation. Using a dedicated web-interface for microtasking to support humanitarian efforts, local domain experts from MCERT examined this evolving sample, performing a two-stage verification. They first checked if the image contained damage content and then assigned a severity level based on a predetermined taxonomy. The research team also developed a detailed tutorial to ensure that all labellers were approaching the task in a consistent manner. The corrections made by the community responders helped to identify common types of errors made by the algorithm. For example, the AI system struggled with images taken from afar or in low-light and poor resolution settings. Isolating this weakness helped the technical team to develop targeted improvements and the response teams to better understand the potential added value of the AI tool for their operations during crisis response. (Source: Nesta UK)

Apple AppStore's creates incentives and standards for developers, hence generating emergent optimization dynamics that result in competitive strength. Apple only touches the system's "high-leverage" points (e.g. policies, security, payment, performance), and the system then largely optimizes itself.

Microsoft has established a strong market "ecosystem" through its technical and commercial platform for developers who use their products. They support the commercialization thanks to the cross-selling those developers can do on the back of Microsoft's market presence. They also control some important high-leverage points of the system, such as security and policies standards to help with trust and control, and collaboration through GitHub. They also support the cybersecurity layer. The result is an emerging, intelligent adaptation of the network.

Use case: Map skills across a local community network
Description: Design collective Atolye, based in Turkey, has used network analysis to enable members to connect more easily, across virtual and physical locations

Use case: Enable concise transfer of knowledge and alignment across network
Description: Amazon’s founder Jeff Bezos famously enforces a concise format for meeting memos, which are religiously read by participants prior to the start of the meeting. Many companies have adopted it.

Curation engines that aggregate content through a combination of human and AI intervention also exist (e.g., Curata but also competitive intelligence tools like XiQ.io or technologies like Discover.ai). The individual person’s ability to efficiently collect and distribute curated knowledge is also the object of recent developments, for example through Factr.

Use case: Protect individual data ownership based on blockchain and other tools, and self-regulation
Description: One of the founding fathers of the web, Tim Berners-Lee, has spearheaded the creation of a set of methods and tools, called Solid, for ensuring individual data ownership. Other initiative, such as blockchain-based Rainfall.one, attempt to address the same challenge, with the added value to promote monetization for the end users in exchange for the data they create. Self-regulation is also a possibility – if internet players move advertising revenue away from selling advertising based on tracked individual tracking history.

Use case: Enable analysis of complex, distributed web based information
Description: With the advances in Natural Language Processing, machines are getting better at helping humans make sense of connections between elements of large content sets – as in the example of Quid.com or Forestreet that can map technology market landscapes and draw connections between market participants and related technologies

Use case: Annotate text to provide better metadata
Description: Human curators can also use web text annotations tools, like getMemex.com, effectively appending metadata to text parcels of browsing history, in a way that’s somewhat like what Amazon Kindle allows to do on kindle-format books.

Use case: Identify patterns in scientific literature for Covid19
Description: In 2020, BenevolentAI came into the limelight for using machine learning and other AI techniques to identify patterns in existing literature through knowledge graphs. As stated on their website “in the face of the growing global health crisis, BenevolentAI set up a specialist scientific team and launched an investigation using its drug discovery platform to identify approved drugs which could potentially stop the progression of COVID-19, inhibit the cytokine storm and reduce the inflammatory damage associated with this disease. Benevolent’s research findings were published in [scientific journals] as a potential treatment with both anti-viral and anti-inflammatory properties, for COVID-19 patients admitted to hospital prior to the development of critical lung damage.”
Epistemonikos, used by the government of Chile to set new health guidelines based on the latest evidence, uses machine learning to identify reevant reviews in the respective scientific literature.

Use case: Enable collaboration for small-scale farmers in Africa
Description: In Africa, Wefarm.co helps millions of small-scale farmers to connect with each other – both through web and SMS - and exchange solutions to their questions.

Who / What: Asana, Basecamp, Hive, Taskade, Unito, Workfront, Wrike
Description: Software in the “collaborative workspace management” attempt to streamline somewhat repetitive and even project-based work that doesn’t fit squarely in a traditional workflow – examples in that space include Wrike, Workfront, Asana, Hive, Unito, Taskade, and Basecamp, as well as other enterprise social media.

Use case: Provide basic help for the home
Description: Hyperconnectivity and the ability to inventory and quality-control millions of people at minimal marginal cost has changed its dynamics radically, effectively surfacing the cognitive surplus of millions of people and reshaping many jobs. Platforms have in many respects created the current “gig economy” movement, and they increasingly show specialization of roles where very specific expertise is harnessed in a way that wasn’t possible before – an idea first publicized by MIT’s Malone and colleagues in 2011

Who / What: Skype, Cisco Webex, Adobe Connect, Citrix GoToMeeting, Google Hangouts, BlueJeans, Zoom, Around, Fuze, Lifesize, Loom, Owl, Starleaf, TechSmith, Hopin
Description: Unified communications are an obvious collaboration environment, specifically catering for synchronous or near-real-time (e.g. chat) interactions.  These interactions are important because many people tend to be more productive and creative when they can bounce off thoughts with each other synchronously (mirror neurons may have something to do with it). This technology space has seen significant advances in the last decade, starting with the disruption that Skype introduced into the telecom industry, but also with entrants competing successfully. The recent coronavirus emergency boosted the adoption of these tools, especially as the cloud- based version of them was already extensively used in organizations, enabling scalability while maintaining an appropriate level of security.

Google launched simultaneous earbuds intended to automatically translate language between two or more people in an in-person meeting – and while the current results are not effective enough for professional use, they will soon be close enough, especially for groups with mixed proficiency of language.

Use case: Enable synchronous collaboration through shared data repositories
Description: Tools that enable collaboration by allowing multiple users access to documentation.
Evidencio enables users to get all relevant medical prediction models from a single online library.

Use case: Turn open-source into easy-to-adopt enterprise software
Description: Data science and information technology leverage virtual collaboration. Linux showed to the world how a coding environment can be created with rules that enable both solid coding and participatory work – and even spawned an ecosystems of successful private enterprises like RedHat (acquired by IBM) that use and extend that code and add additional services on top of it (eg maintenance.)

Another attempt to give large, decentralized life sciences and possibly other scientific communities new methods for doing research, JOGL (Just One Giant Lab) has created a technology platform that enables sharing of resources and attempts to provide the foundational infrastructure needed for participatory and decentralized innovation.

Colony.io attempts to create a protocol for interoperability between an emerging set of technologies based on Ethereum, for instance, and is focused on the management of the human resources – in contrast to Augur (predictions), golem.network (distributed computing power) and 0x.org (exchange of tokens).

There are some experimental examples of platforms intended to create radically new organizational structures, whereby people work on the tasks that they like and they’re competent for, and they get fairly rewarded for it. They borrow some of the concepts of holocracy (used for instance at retailer Zappos, software firm Satalia, or to an extent videogames producer Valve).

Use case: Optimize allocation of resources (people and machines' time...) to tasks
Description: Where appropriate and possible allocate work deliberately, for instance with a sort of ticketing system whose algorithm matches resources with tasks. It is also possible for contributors to decide where to work out of the open tasks. In the examples Wikipedia and Linux, for instance, the latter option is adopted, but contributions are subjugated to contributors having the right credentials.

Use case: Reach out to communities and networks
Description: At the same time, a strong “marketing” muscle can help. Outreach tools, starting with social media (e.g. Dux-soup, Followers DM, or Sprinklr.) They can also start celebrating punctuations of the lifecycle of the new network (think of what Change.org does), and in general create an amount of drumbeat that makes the network’s pulse felt.
Lexica.art is a search engine that finds Stable Diffusion AI text-to-image artwork in an ever-growing database, built on prompts by thousands of people.
